title: Will we ever explore the aquatic side of League?
body: We have a few water based champions, but what goes on beneath the sea is a mystery. Perhaps that's intentional, but I'd love to see what crazy creatures live in the deeper parts of the ocean.

All I have to go off is the background from Burning Tides:
http://i.imgur.com/WqpQlJq.jpg

You can see the carcasses of a few sea creatures already hacked up.  There's one dude in the picture background to help us with scale, but maybe more useful is the pair of [longboats](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Longboat) further towards the back.  That hanging carcass looks at least 6.5 longboats long.

Longboats are around 25ft long (7.6m) so that'd make that particular critter around 162ft (50m).  I'm going to guess that's a pretty normal size for a catch round there, seeing as the cranes and ramps look easily capable of handing a fish that big.

As for the bearded monster in the original image... uh that looks like a brig to me?  They're pretty big.  Pretty sure that's not a toy boat that you play with in the bath.

Fit's whith what I thought, 50 meter is a fair size for a vessel of that setting, a large Brig or average Galleon (the Black Pearl for example is almost 60m).

There are some creatures that seem a bit larger than the hanging one, but overall "about ship sized" seems right.

Now for the "Bearded Lady", measuring curves is a bit finicky, but I say it's at least 50 of that ship's lengths. Even if we take that for a smaller Brig (30m) we are looking at a creatures that measures at least a mile, possibly two.

Well mantas are really cool, but there is a bit beyond that. Rek'sai is violent, territorial, and down-right mean. To set another non-sentient champion apart from her a "gentle giant" approach would be good. So barring making up a completely new creature (which runs the risk of being too alien) starting with a base of whale or manta ray. I would avoid most fish because I don't believe that the side to side motion of their tales would look good in game. The primary reason I thought of mantas is that compared to other sea creatures they would look non-offensive hovering above the ground.

So while you may combine other things into the ray form, or change the details of it to make it more magical. I think that keeping the flattened form is what would look best in game.

Where they mention that everything looked like void babies. If you don't want it to be confused with creatures from the void it's important that it looks "natural" in some way.
